text.p: Following are the main stories in Croatian newspapers on Wednesday.
VJESNIK
- President Franjo Tudjman is to set a date today for local elections in the country, including the last Serb-run enclave of Eastern Slavonia.

- Croatia's Defence and National Security Council expressed concern over latest bloody incidents in Mostar. It said Croatia would urge the city's Bosnian Croats and Moslems to solve all problems through peaceful negotiations.
- Cable television is conquering Croatia. The state telecommunications council receives 34 bids for cable TV concessions.

- Dalmatian hotelier Suncani Hvar d.d. is to invest some 100,000 German marks in renovating the Sirena hotel and some 200,000 marks to improve the power supply system in all its hotels on the island of Hvar.
- Rijeka oil rafinery 1996 production fell 6.7 percent from 1995.
VECERNJI LIST

- Croatian citizens who earned their pensions in other republics of ex-Yugoslavia will not receive a 10 percent increase applicable to Croatian pensions, until the government reaches interstate agreements with those countries.

- Food imports shrank only 0.54 percent in 1996 from a year before, but exports rose 2.64 percent. Croatia spent most money -- $90 million on importing fruit and $80 million on milk and dairy products.
- A large spread between current interbank rates and banks' lending rates for corporate borrowers show a slow reaction to positive developments on the money market.
- Capital market: Shares in troubled Privredna Banka Zagreb were strongly in demand last week, mostly by 'big' buyers who obviously believe the bank has good prospects of recovery.
- Implementation of the new bankruptcy law may not cause liquidation of insolvent firms, but their directors may now face jail sentence for payment default instead.
- State bank HBOR is mulling new credit lines to help exporters, says its president Anton Kovacev.
SLOBODNA DALMACIJA
- Commentary: Local elections may be postponed until April 13.
- Better links between the islands are the only guarantee of their development, says transport minister Zeljko Luzavec.
- Another round of talks between the Education Ministry and secondary school teachers' union ends in failure. Union threatens a strike on February 20.
- Interview with economy minister Davor Stern: I would like to see a smaller share of services in the 1997 GDP.
- Pensions or handouts? New pension law makes no radical changes, say M. Rakelic in a commentary.
- A new underground hydro-electric power plant to be built north of Dubrovnik. HE Ombla's production estimated at 156.3 million kWh a year. -- Zagreb Newsroom, 385-1-4557075
